description:
Bradyrhizobium algeriense is a species of nitrogen-fixing bacteria that was first isolated from root nodules of leguminous plants in Algeria. It is a slow-growing, aerobic, gram-negative bacterium that belongs to the genus Bradyrhizobium, which is known for its ability to form symbiotic relationships with legumes and fix atmospheric nitrogen.

The cells of B. algeriense are typically rod-shaped, with a size range of 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.2-2.5 μm in length. They are motile, with the help of a single polar flagellum. The bacterium is capable of growing at temperatures ranging from 20°C to 35°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 28°C.

Phylogenetic analysis based on the 16S rRNA gene sequence has shown that B. algeriense is closely related to other Bradyrhizobium species, such as B. japonicum and B. elkanii, which are also known for their nitrogen-fixing abilities in symbiosis with legumes.

The ability of B. algeriense to form effective root nodules and fix atmospheric nitrogen is an important characteristic, as it can contribute to the improvement of soil fertility and the growth of leguminous crops in regions where it is found. Further research on the ecological and agronomic significance of this species may provide insights into its potential applications in sustainable agriculture and soil management.
